results_summary: The nutritional packet improved feed efficiency initially, increased overall intake, enhanced nutrient digestibility, and improved dressing percentage and ruminal papillae area, though body weight gain remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Angus crossbred steer-calves (N=60; initial body weight 234±4 kg).
effective_dosage: 30 g/steer-daily (dry matter basis), containing live yeast, vitamin C, vitamin B1, sodium chloride, and potassium chloride.
study_duration: 233 days (administered during the first and last 60 days on feed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how pre-stretching affects the ionic conductivity, mechanical properties, and electrochemical performance of polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based polymer electrolytes for flexible batteries.
results_summary: Pre-stretching (50-80% pre-strain) significantly increased through-plane ionic conductivity (1.6x), in-plane strength and stiffness (120-140%), and cell-specific capacity while reducing modulus and hardness in the thickness direction. Adding nanoceramics further enhanced these effects by reducing crystallinity and increasing free volume size.
population_specificity: PEO-based polymer electrolytes (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: To determine if urine electrolyte assessments can monitor the adequacy of mineralocorticoid therapy in dogs with hypoadrenocorticism treated with desoxycorticosterone pivalate (DOCP).
results_summary: Urine potassium-to-creatinine (K:Cr) ratios were significantly associated with serum potassium concentrations at 10-14 days and 30 days post-DOCP injection, but the associations were weak (low R² values). Urine K:Cr ratios were higher in overtreated dogs compared to undertreated dogs at 10-14 days, but no other urine variables differed significantly between groups.
population_specificity: 29 dogs with naturally occurring glucocorticoid- and mineralocorticoid-deficient hypoadrenocorticism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum electrolyte levels in patients with acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD) versus stable COPD and correlate these imbalances with disease severity and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that AECOPD patients had lower mean serum sodium and calcium levels and higher potassium levels, with hyponatremia being the most frequent abnormality. Patients with multiple electrolyte imbalances had poorer outcomes, including higher mortality and prolonged hospital stays.
population_specificity: Patients with AECOPD (41 cases) and stable COPD (34 controls), predominantly aged 61-70.
study_duration: Study conducted between January 2021 and December 2022 (duration of intervention not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the addition of graphene oxide to a silicate-hypophosphite electrolyte affects the properties and tribological performance of plasma electrolytic oxidation coatings on Ti6Al4V titanium alloys.
results_summary: The study found that adding graphene oxide (GO) to the electrolyte reduced the coefficient of friction (from 0.73 to 0.69) and decreased the wear rate by more than 1.5 times (from 8.04 to 5.2 mm³/N·m) with increasing GO concentration (0 to 0.5 kg/m³). The improvement was attributed to the formation of a GO-containing lubricating tribolayer, which also slowed down coating delamination by more than four times.
population_specificity: Ti6Al4V titanium alloy surfaces treated with plasma electrolytic oxidation.
effective_dosage: Graphene oxide concentrations of 0 to 0.5 kg/m³ in the electrolyte.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of thyroid hormone withdrawal (THW) and recombinant human thyrotropin (rhTSH) on serum electrolyte levels during radioactive iodine therapy (RIT) and identify clinical factors influencing hyponatremia and hyperkalemia.
results_summary: THW led to significantly lower sodium and chloride levels and higher potassium levels compared to rhTSH. Age and renal function were key factors influencing hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, respectively.
population_specificity: 278 patients with thyroid cancer undergoing RIT from April 2005 to December 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) treatment on mediators of endothelial dysfunction and electrolyte levels in women with preeclampsia.
results_summary: MgSO₄ treatment significantly reduced adrenomedullin (AM), soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (sICAM-1), and sodium (Na⁺) levels while increasing calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and magnesium (Mg²⁺) levels, with more pronounced effects in severe preeclampsia compared to mild cases.
population_specificity: 100 pregnant women (50 severe preeclampsia, 50 mild preeclampsia) and 50 normotensive pregnant controls from Sampa Government Hospital, Ghana.
study_duration: Measurements taken before treatment, 24 hours after MgSO₄ treatment, and 48 hours after delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antihypertensive and cardioprotective effects of intravenous hinokitiol in angiotensin II-induced hypertensive emergency in rats.
results_summary: Hinokitiol at 10 mg/kg significantly reduced systolic blood pressure by 30 mmHg within 30 minutes, likely due to decreased peripheral resistance and cardiac load, without affecting baroreflex sensitivity or sodium/potassium balance.
population_specificity: Rats with angiotensin II-induced hypertensive emergency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of TKIs (Imatinib and Nilotinib) on liver enzymes and serum electrolytes in relation to hematologic and molecular response in CP-CML patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in serum sodium, potassium, phosphorous, or calcium levels after treatment with either Imatinib or Nilotinib, indicating no adverse electrolyte effects. However, liver enzymes (AST, ALT, ALP) were significantly increased post-treatment.
population_specificity: 38 newly diagnosed Philadelphia-positive CP-CML patients (20-62 years) with normal hepatic and renal function, excluding HCV-, HBV-, and HIV-positive individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability of sulfide-based solid electrolytes for all-solid-state lithium batteries by doping with metal oxides.
results_summary: The metal-oxide-doped Li7P2S8I0.75Br0.25 solid electrolyte showed higher ionic conductivity (7.3 mS cm-1) and improved electrochemical stability, with the Ta2O5-doped variant remaining stable after 300 charge-discharge cycles and 100 hours of dry-air exposure. The ASSB using this electrolyte achieved a discharge capacity of 184 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C rate.
population_specificity: Not applicable (materials science study).
study_duration: Not specified (evaluated over 300 charge-discharge cycles and 100 hours of dry-air exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of macrogol/electrolytes with magnesium hydroxide in preventing opioid-induced constipation (OIC) in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study is designed to assess non-inferiority of magnesium hydroxide compared to macrogol/electrolytes in preventing OIC, with primary outcomes measured via the Bowel Function Index (BFI) and secondary outcomes including side effects, tolerability, and cost-effectiveness. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Patients with incurable cancer starting opioid therapy for pain management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) in managing electrolyte disturbances in critically ill patients with acute kidney injury (AKI).
results_summary: CRRT was found to provide better hemodynamic stability and steady correction of electrolyte disturbances compared to intermittent hemodialysis, though it carries risks of paradoxical electrolyte imbalances like hypokalemia or hypophosphatemia under certain conditions. Optimal management requires individualized fluid prescriptions and close monitoring.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with AKI and electrolyte disorders.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varies based on individualized prescriptions).
study_duration: Not specified (depends on treatment duration and patient condition).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reducing the thickness and utilizing a lamellar framework of vermiculite-based ceramic electrolytes could improve ionic conductivity for use in all-solid-state lithium batteries.
results_summary: The study found that the ion-exchanged expanded vermiculite (IEVMT) thin film exhibited excellent ionic conductivity (0.310 S·cm-1 at 600 °C) with low excitation energy, along with good mechanical and thermal stability. The results suggest that thin, lamellar frameworks can effectively enhance ionic conductivity in solid electrolytes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different nitrogen-doped configurations in a porous carbon matrix affect electrochemical performance in aqueous and ionic liquid gel electrolytes for supercapacitors.
results_summary: The study found that pyridinic-N enhances pseudocapacitance, yielding high specific capacitance (436.1 F g-1) and stability (100% retention after 5000 cycles), while graphitic-N improves electrical double-layer capacitance, achieving a maximum energy density of 125.4 Wh kg-1.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a Nutritional Packet containing electrolytes and other nutrients on growth performance, carcass characteristics, nutrient digestibility, and feeding behavior in beef steers during the final 64 days of the feedlot-finishing phase.
results_summary: The Nutritional Packet improved nutrient digestibility and carcass fat deposition without affecting growth performance or most carcass quality indices. It also led to more consistent feeding behavior patterns compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Angus-crossbred beef steers (initial body weight = 544 ± 52 kg).
effective_dosage: 30 g per steer daily (dry matter basis), providing 2.4 g NaCl and 2.4 g KCl per steer daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate volemia and electrolyte status from a clinical cardiorenal viewpoint using artificial intelligence to assess the interdependence of sodium, potassium, and other variables.
results_summary: The study found that both sodium and potassium levels significantly impact patient condition and vital endangerment, with B-type natriuretic peptide having the greatest influence on ejection fraction. The AI model identified a prognostic biomarker to predict risks of electrolyte disturbance and hypervolemia, potentially improving diagnostic accuracy and treatment planning.
population_specificity: Patients assessed from a clinical cardiorenal perspective (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current progress in recycling methods for aged electrolytes from spent lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and present perspectives on future development of electrolyte recycling.
results_summary: The study highlights the environmental and health risks posed by aged organic electrolytes in spent LIBs, including toxicity and fluorine pollution, and discusses challenges in recycling them, such as volatility, flammability, and compositional variability. It reviews existing recycling methods and suggests future directions for improvement.
population_specificity: Not applicable (focus on environmental and industrial recycling, not human consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate Li thiophosphate solid electrolytes containing BH4- anions for improved safety and high ionic conductivity in Li-ion batteries.
results_summary: The synthesized solid electrolytes exhibited high ionic conductivity (up to 11 mS cm-1 at 25 °C), surpassing reported values. The thiophosphate local structure was found to influence conductivity, which could be adjusted by varying LiBH4 amounts and milling conditions, leading to superior cycle and rate performances in all-solid-state cells.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the correlation of hemoglobin (Hgb), sodium (Na+), and potassium (K+) values between a blood gas analyzer and a laboratory autoanalyzer in emergency department patients.
results_summary: The study found a strong positive correlation between POC testing and laboratory methods for Hgb, Na+, and K+, with mean differences within acceptable clinical ranges. The results suggest that therapy based on blood gas analyzer findings may improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: Emergency Department patients requiring venous gas analysis, complete blood count, and electrolytes.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (comparative study, not an intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate evidence-based treatment approaches involving electrolytes (Mg, Ca) in complementary and alternative medicine for urological oncologists.
results_summary: The study found that electrolyte supplementation should be based on laboratory-observed deficits, but no specific benefit or recommendation was highlighted for electrolytes (Mg, Ca) in cancer patients.
population_specificity: Urological cancer patients (specific population not detailed beyond this).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate regional changes in blood gas values and electrolytes in occluded vessels to determine if these changes could predict outcomes in large vessel occlusion (LVO) patients receiving endovascular treatment (EVT).
results_summary: Significant decreases in K+, Ca2+, HCO3-, BE, HCT, tHbc, and TCO2 levels were observed in proximal luminal blood before EVT. Proximal/femoral ratios of pH and Na+ were associated with short-term clinical outcomes and successful recanalization.
population_specificity: 45 consecutive ischemic stroke patients with LVO of the anterior circulation.
study_duration: Not specified (blood samples taken before and after EVT)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structure and dynamics of water at gamma-alumina interfaces and the influence of different salts on these properties.
results_summary: The study found stronger water interaction with the [110] surface compared to [100], with ion-induced disruption of water structure more prevalent at the [100] surface. Cations like sodium and ammonium showed stronger association, influenced by ion size, and surface characteristics played a fundamental role in determining interactions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (molecular dynamics simulation study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of catheter-based renal denervation (RDN) on electrolytes (serum and urinary sodium and potassium) as part of its broader impact on hypertension regulation.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in serum sodium, serum potassium, urinary sodium, or urinary potassium levels after RDN, indicating that RDN did not significantly affect electrolyte balance.
population_specificity: 771 persons (from 20 studies, including two randomized controlled trials and 18 observational studies).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention was catheter-based RDN, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synthesis parameters on the structure and ionic conductivity of Li2ZrCl6 electrolytes and explore strategies to enhance their performance for use in all-solid-state lithium metal batteries.
results_summary: Mild heat treatment (100 °C) significantly enhanced the ionic conductivity of Li2ZrCl6 by 2-3 times, attributed to a network-like micromorphology beneficial for lithium ion migration. The modified Li2ZrCl6 demonstrated high initial charge capacity (176.4 mAh g-1) and maintained 90.8 mAh g-1 after 40 cycles in battery tests.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the biological pathway by which the DASH diet, through changes in electrolyte ratios, leads to blood pressure reduction.
results_summary: The study found that shifting from a high-sodium/low-potassium diet to the DASH diet increased serum aldosterone, reduced urine electrolyte ratio ([Na]/[K]), and lowered blood pressure by a mean of 3.7 mmHg systolic and 2.3 mmHg diastolic.
population_specificity: Nine volunteers admitted for an inpatient trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lactate- and acetate-containing balanced crystalloid solutions on acid-base status, electrolytes, and lactate values in dogs with fluid deficits.
results_summary: Both solutions similarly reduced heart rate, but the acetate-containing solution significantly decreased plasma lactate, anion gap, and potassium while increasing chloride and ionized calcium. The lactate-containing solution also reduced anion gap, sodium, and potassium while increasing chloride, though acetate showed stronger effects in some parameters.
population_specificity: Client-owned dogs presenting with signs of fluid deficits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a safer and more efficient electrolyte for sodium rechargeable batteries by using fluorinated phosphate solvents to improve reversibility and safety.
results_summary: The study found that fluorinated phosphate solvents enhanced the reversibility of Na plating/stripping and improved safety, achieving 83.4% capacity retention after 200 cycles with an average Coulombic efficiency of 99.6%. The electrolyte also demonstrated compatibility with a high-voltage cathode.
population_specificity: Sodium rechargeable batteries (laboratory setting).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between fludrocortisone (FC) dose, electrolyte levels (sodium, potassium), renin, and clinical parameters in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency (PAI).
results_summary: FC dose showed dose-dependent effects on sodium (positive correlation) and potassium/renin (negative correlations). Long-term follow-up (>60 months) showed reduced FC doses, while higher doses were observed in autoimmune PAI patients with low-normal renin. Electrolyte imbalances were noted in high-renin patients, but cardiovascular events were similar across renin/FC dose groups.
population_specificity: 193 patients with primary adrenal insufficiency (130 autoimmune).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review electrolyte disturbances in cancer patients, their causes, pathophysiology, and management strategies.
results_summary: The study found that certain cancer drugs can cause electrolyte disturbances, such as hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcaemia, and highlighted the need for early recognition and timely management.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether surface functionalization of structural electrodes with silane could improve ion conduction efficiency and multifunctional performance in composite supercapacitors.
results_summary: Treating carbon fiber electrodes coated with manganese dioxide using silane increased areal capacitance by 300% without compromising tensile strength. The dual-phase electrolyte (40 wt% ionic liquid, 60 wt% epoxy) exhibited the highest multifunctional performance, combining stiffness and ionic conductivity.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on composite materials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the physiological changes in acid-base balance and electrolyte metabolism (sodium and calcium) during pregnancy.
results_summary: The study found that pregnancy induces mild respiratory alkalosis, physiological hyponatremia, and significant changes in calcium metabolism, including increased absorption and potential risks of hypo- or hypercalcemia. Gestational diabetes insipidus and starvation ketosis were also noted as potential complications.
population_specificity: Pregnant women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel ethanol-mediated synthesis route for superionic Li3InCl6 electrolyte to improve its thermal stability, ionic conductivity, and compatibility with high-voltage electrodes for all-solid-state lithium-metal batteries.
results_summary: The ethanol-mediated synthesis produced Li3InCl6 with high ionic conductivity (0.79 mS cm-1 at 20°C) and excellent thermal stability. The assembled battery demonstrated high initial charge capacity (174.8 mAh g-1 at 0.05 C), good rate performance (122.9 mAh g-1 at 1 C), and high retention rate (94.8% after 200 cycles).
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability and energy density of lithium metal batteries using tailored garnet-type LLZO solid electrolytes, focusing on compatibility between LLZO and lithium metal.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that bulk dopant regulation and dopant-specific interfacial treatment significantly improved stability and energy density, achieving a cumulative capacity of over 4000 mAh cm-2 at 3 mA cm-2, the highest reported for Li-metal batteries with LLZOs.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on battery materials, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the ionic conductivity of hexagonal Li4SnS4-based solid electrolytes while maintaining air stability by adding LiI and Li3PS4.
results_summary: The study found that adding LiI and Li3PS4 to hexagonal Li4SnS4 significantly increased ionic conductivity (up to 5.5 × 10-4 S cm-1) without compromising air stability. The optimized electrolyte (0.37LiI·0.25Li3PS4·0.38Li4SnS4) showed improved rate performance in all-solid-state batteries compared to unmodified Li4SnS4.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of tofogliflozin on serum electrolytes, cardiac function, and glycemic control in elderly Japanese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Tofogliflozin improved glycemic control and cardiac diastolic function (E/e') without negatively affecting serum electrolytes, renal function, or regulatory hormones. Most hormonal, electrolyte, and physiological parameters remained stable throughout the study.
population_specificity: Elderly Japanese patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (n=64).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relationship between blood pressure status, dietary factors, and serum electrolytes among in-school adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that higher sodium intake and lower potassium intake were associated with elevated blood pressure, with a significant negative relationship between serum potassium and systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: 488 secondary school students aged 10-19 years in Ilishan-Remo, Ogun State, Nigeria.
effective_dosage: Estimated mean dietary intakes were 2289±938.7 mg/person/day for sodium and 1321±603.8 mg/person/day for potassium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of ZIF-8/PVA/GA composite membranes for use in direct alkaline methanol fuel cells, focusing on ionic conductivity, mechanical strength, and stability.
results_summary: The study found that PVA/40.5%ZIF-8/GA composites exhibited significantly improved ionic conductivity (21% higher than base material), reduced alcohol permeability (94% lower), and enhanced mechanical strength and alkaline stability. The composite also showed negligible conductivity loss after 168 hours of alkaline treatment and achieved a 181% increase in maximum power density compared to non-ZIF-8 membranes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on composite membranes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of supporting electrolytes, particularly inert cations, on electro-osmotic instability and electroconvection in a multi-component electrolyte system.
results_summary: The study found that inert cations suppressed a known electro-osmotic instability and induced remote electroconvection along the azimuthal direction. A distinctive inert-cation concentration valley propagated radially outward, with its correlation to electroconvection visualized at a microscopic level.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based electrochemical system)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fluoride-free organic electrolytes (NaAlO2 and Na2SiO3) in forming anodic layers on 304L stainless steel and their corrosion resistance properties.
results_summary: The study found that anodizing in Na2SiO3-electrolyte with low H2O concentrations produced oxide layers with improved corrosion resistance, while NaAlO2-electrolyte resulted in poor adherence and chemical stability. The optimal condition (glycerol, 0.05 M Na2SiO3, 1.7 vol% H2O at 20 mA/cm2 for 6 min) enhanced corrosion resistance by approximately one order of magnitude compared to non-anodized steel.
population_specificity: 304L stainless steel substrates
effective_dosage: 0.05 M Na2SiO3, 1.7 vol% H2O at 20 mA/cm2

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the short-term effects of three magnesium supplements (oxide, citrate, carbonate) on magnesium biochemical status and electrolyte levels in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Mg oxide increased ionized Mg concentration and % in total Mg, Mg citrate increased ionized fraction but decreased serum total Mg, and Mg carbonate decreased ionized Mg without affecting total Mg. Mg oxide showed superior bioavailability without altering other minerals' levels.
population_specificity: Healthy female young adults (n=61)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of khat on spatial learning and memory and their correlation with serum electrolytes, particularly calcium, sodium, potassium, and chloride.
results_summary: Subchronic administration of khat extract and juice impaired spatial learning and memory, with higher doses (200 mg/kg and 300 mg/kg) showing significant negative effects. Serum calcium levels were inversely correlated with escape latency, suggesting a link between electrolyte imbalance and cognitive impairment.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg, 200 mg/kg, 300 mg/kg (crude khat extract); 2.5 mL/kg (khat juice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the consequences of asymmetry in ionic size and valence in charged fluids, particularly in the context of electrical double layers, beyond classical Poisson-Boltzmann theory.
results_summary: The study discusses the limitations of the non-linear Poisson-Boltzmann theory and examines the effects of ion correlations and excluded volume in charged fluids under external fields, using advanced theoretical and simulation methods.
population_specificity: Theoretical study (no human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of time elapsed after oral furosemide administration on urine chemistry, particularly electrolyte excretion, in dogs with myxomatous mitral valve disease (MMVD) in ACVIM stage C.
results_summary: The study found that urinary sodium and chloride excretion, as well as the urine sodium to potassium ratio, were significantly higher within 6 hours of furosemide administration in MMVD dogs compared to later sampling or healthy dogs. No differences were observed between healthy morning and evening groups or between MMVD and healthy evening groups.
population_specificity: 73 dogs with MMVD ACVIM stage C and 106 healthy dogs.
effective_dosage: Not specified (oral furosemide administration timing was the focus).
study_duration: Not specified (single sampling time points were compared).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy, safety, and acceptability of polyethylene glycol (PEG) 3350 and magnesium hydroxide (MH) as long-term treatments for functional constipation in pediatric patients aged 6 months to 18 years.
results_summary: Both PEG 3350 and MH were equally effective and safe for treating functional constipation in children, with no significant differences in success rates or adverse events. However, PEG 3350 had better acceptability in patients above 4 years of age.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients aged 6 months to 18 years diagnosed with functional constipation.

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of 25 mg/day spironolactone on serum electrolytes and kidney function in patients with severe chronic left-sided heart failure.
results_summary: Spironolactone significantly increased serum potassium levels without exceeding clinically accepted ranges, while no significant changes were observed in serum sodium, creatinine, or blood urea. The control group showed no significant changes in these parameters.
population_specificity: 60 patients with severe chronic left-sided heart failure.
interactions: Monitoring recommended for patients also using ACEI and ARBs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal hydration scheme, including electrolyte supplementation, to prevent cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity (CIN).
results_summary: Seven out of nine studies found that magnesium supplementation reduced the risk of nephrotoxicity, while short hydration schemes and mannitol were also effective in preventing CIN.
population_specificity: Patients receiving cisplatin therapy (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different alkalinizing agents in oral electrolyte solutions (OES) and the presence of milk replacer feeding on the abomasal environment in healthy Holstein calves.
results_summary: Postprandial pH was higher in calves fed milk replacer or bicarbonate-based OES, while abomasal emptying was slower with milk replacer + OES. Bicarbonate OES and milk replacer promoted E. coli growth, whereas acetate OES limited it.
population_specificity: Healthy Holstein bull calves (5 days old at cannulation, 9 days old at treatment assignment).
effective_dosage: 2 L of OES, administered once (with or without prior milk replacer feeding).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the challenges and importance of providing adequate micronutrients, including electrolytes, to premature neonates due to limited data and nutritional shortages.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the difficulties in assessing and supplementing micronutrients in premature neonates but does not provide specific findings on electrolytes' effects.
population_specificity: Premature neonates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding glucose to balanced crystalloids could mitigate hospital-related caloric intake drops and modify catabolic status in acutely admitted older adults.
results_summary: The study found that adding glucose to balanced crystalloids led to a significantly higher incidence of refeeding syndrome (83.3% vs. 16.7%), marked by drops in phosphates, potassium, and/or magnesium. The intervention induced an anabolic shift of electrolytes but posed notable risks.
population_specificity: Acutely admitted older adults (78 years and older) with non-traumatic illnesses.
effective_dosage: Balanced crystalloid enriched with 100 g of glucose per liter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a high-energy, low-protein formula (HE-LPF) as a partial or total meal replacement in pre-dialysis CKD patients following a low-protein diet.
results_summary: The HE-LPF group showed a significant decrease in the percentage of energy derived from protein, indicating the formula's effectiveness in altering dietary protein intake. No other specific outcomes or adverse effects were detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Stage 4-5 chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients on a low-protein diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of teduglutide in reducing intravenous supplementation (IVS) dependence and improving health-related quality of life in patients with short bowel syndrome with intestinal failure (SBS-IF).
results_summary: The study found that daily subcutaneous administration of teduglutide was clinically effective in reducing IVS dependence and potentially improving the health-related quality of life for SBS-IF patients. The management of SBS-IF patients requires close monitoring, and the study discusses the screening, initiation, and monitoring of teduglutide treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome with intestinal failure (SBS-IF).
effective_dosage: Daily subcutaneous administration (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to define and classify short bowel syndrome (SBS) and its relation to chronic intestinal failure (CIF), including the role of intravenous supplementation (IVS) for maintaining health.
results_summary: The abstract describes the classification of SBS based on anatomical, evolutional, pathophysiological, and clinical criteria but does not provide specific results regarding electrolytes or their effects.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) and chronic intestinal failure (CIF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the significance of magnesium in cancer patients, focusing on hypomagnesemia's causes, symptoms, and management strategies.
results_summary: The study highlights the importance of magnesium monitoring in cancer patients, identifies cancer therapies contributing to hypomagnesemia, and reviews effective supplementation methods for treatment-resistant cases.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with hypomagnesemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the current pharmacological management of short bowel syndrome-associated intestinal failure, focusing on emerging treatments like enterohormone therapy.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that enterohormone therapy may reduce the need for parenteral support and improve quality of life in patients with short bowel syndrome-associated intestinal failure.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome-associated chronic intestinal failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether orally administered potassium nitrate would decrease blood pressure and increase GFR and urinary sodium excretion in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found no differences in GFR, blood pressure, or sodium excretion between potassium nitrate and placebo treatments, despite increased nitrate and nitrite levels in plasma and urine. Healthy subjects may compensate for nitrate supplementation effects under steady-state conditions.
population_specificity: 18 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the occurrence and significance of hypomagnesemia in patients with intestinal lymphangiectasia (IL) and assess the effectiveness of treatment with a medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) diet and nutrient supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that hypomagnesemia is an overlooked complication of IL, and treatment with an MCT diet and nutrient supplementation yielded satisfactory results in alleviating symptoms. A systematic review of published literature supported these findings.
population_specificity: A 30-year-old Tibetan woman with IL and chronic diarrhea, edema, tetany, and tingling, along with a review of other IL cases from published literature.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the historical progression, complications, and management of home parenteral nutrition (HPN) including electrolytes for patients with chronic intestinal failure (CIF).
results_summary: The study highlights that HPN, including electrolytes, is essential for sustaining growth and health in CIF patients but notes common complications related to central venous catheters and PN itself, such as thrombosis, infections, and liver disease. Education on prevention and prompt management of complications is emphasized as key to maintaining health and quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic intestinal failure (CIF) requiring home parenteral nutrition (HPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of graded dosages of oral phenylalanine and serine in healthy male adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of phenylalanine or serine.
population_specificity: Healthy male adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of rapid renutrition, including electrolyte substitution, in severely malnourished patients with anorexia nervosa.
results_summary: The study found that rapid renutrition with electrolyte substitution was safe under thorough medical surveillance, with no evidence of refeeding syndrome except for hyperhydration. Severely malnourished patients showed significant health improvements on a high-calorie diet.
population_specificity: Patients with anorexia nervosa, including those with a BMI of 13 or less.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate gut-targeted interventions for managing uremia, fluid overload, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that intestinal dialysis, oral adsorbents like AST-120, dietary modifications, and microbiota modulation show promise in reducing uremic toxins and electrolyte imbalances, though most findings are preliminary and require further clinical validation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between serum potassium and magnesium levels and the incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF) after cardiac surgery.
results_summary: Lower serum potassium levels (<4.5 mmol/L) were associated with an increased risk of AF, while magnesium supplementation was linked to a higher risk of AF. Magnesium levels alone did not show a significant association with AF risk.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery in a UK cardiac intensive care unit between 2013 and 2017.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of galacto-oligosaccharides (Oligomate) on serum electrolytes and other blood parameters in severely malnourished infants, focusing on gastrointestinal symptoms.
results_summary: Prebiotic supplementation significantly reduced sodium levels and improved hemoglobin, hematocrit, and white blood cell counts, while potassium levels remained unchanged except for a temporary increase in phase 2. Total bilirubin levels increased in phase 3.
population_specificity: Severely malnourished infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare current practices of micronutrient (including electrolytes) administration in critically ill children across three centers with the new ESPGHAN/ESPEN/ESPR/CSPEN guidelines.
results_summary: The study found substantial differences in micronutrient (including electrolytes) administration protocols among the three centers, with deviations from guideline recommendations, particularly for vitamins. The differences were partly due to limitations of available commercial products and lack of strong evidence supporting the guidelines.
population_specificity: Critically ill children in pediatric intensive care units (PICUs).
effective_dosage: Varies by center: Leuven (4-hour infusion), Rotterdam (8-hour infusion for vitamins/trace elements, 24-hour for electrolytes), Edmonton (1-hour infusion for vitamins/trace elements, electrolytes on demand).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the current state of the art and future directions for research in intestinal failure (IF), including the role of electrolytes in its management.
results_summary: The study emphasizes the rarity of IF and the need for multidisciplinary management to improve patient outcomes, but does not provide specific findings on electrolytes.
population_specificity: Patients with intestinal failure (types I, II, and III).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of teduglutide in improving intestinal absorption and reducing parenteral support dependency in patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) and chronic intestinal failure.
results_summary: The study found that teduglutide increased urine production and reduced the need for parenteral support volume in SBS patients with chronic intestinal failure, supporting its use as a first-choice treatment according to ESPEN Guidelines.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) and chronic intestinal failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the consequences of short bowel syndrome (SBS) on hydro-electrolytic abnormalities and the effectiveness of treatments like parenteral nutrition (PN), GLP-2 analogs, and surgical interventions in managing these abnormalities.
results_summary: The study found that SBS leads to hydro-electrolytic abnormalities due to reduced intestinal absorption. Treatments such as GLP-2 analogs significantly reduce PN dependency and improve quality of life, while rehabilitative surgery aims to restore digestive continuity.
population_specificity: Patients with short bowel syndrome (SBS) resulting from extensive small intestine resection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the approaches of different international HPN centers in providing home parenteral nutrition (HPN) and the types of intravenous supplementation (IVS)-admixtures prescribed to patients with chronic intestinal failure (CIF).
results_summary: The study found that HPN provision and IVS-admixture types varied significantly among countries, HPN centers, and between benign-CIF and malignant-CIF. Customized admixtures (CA and CAFE) were more common in benign-CIF, while premixed admixtures (PA and PAFE) prevailed in malignant-CIF.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic intestinal failure (CIF), including those with benign (90.1%) and malignant (9.9%) diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the risks, clinical manifestations, and management strategies of Refeeding Syndrome (RS), focusing on electrolyte imbalances (hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia) in malnourished patients receiving nutritional therapy.
results_summary: The study found that RS involves dangerous electrolyte shifts (hypophosphatemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia) and metabolic disturbances, particularly in malnourished patients. Preventive measures, including electrolyte correction, thiamine supplementation, and hypocaloric feeding, are crucial before initiating nutritional support.
population_specificity: Malnourished patients with gastrointestinal disorders (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, liver cirrhosis, chronic intestinal failure) or prolonged dysphagia requiring endoscopic gastrostomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence-based guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO), including prevention strategies and considerations for special patient groups.
results_summary: The study found that adhesion formation might be reduced by minimally invasive techniques and adhesion barriers, and non-operative treatment is effective in most ASBO cases unless contraindications like peritonitis or ischemia are present. CT is recommended when the etiology is unclear or contraindications for non-operative management are suspected.
population_specificity: Patients with adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO), particularly those with a history of abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a six-week creatine-electrolyte (CE) supplementation intervention improved overall and repeated peak and mean power output during repeated cycling sprints with 2-minute recovery periods.
results_summary: The study found a 4% increase in overall peak power and concluded that CE supplementation improves overall and repeated short-duration sprint cycling performance when sprints are interspersed with adequate recovery periods.
population_specificity: 23 male recreational cyclists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a nutrition support team (NST) on reducing electrolyte abnormalities (EAs) in hospitalized adults receiving parenteral nutrition (PN).
results_summary: The study found that after NST implementation, fewer electrolyte abnormalities (53%) were observed in PN patients, and mortality rates decreased. The results suggest that interdisciplinary team management of PN can reduce negative outcomes.
population_specificity: Hospitalized adults receiving parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: To summarize recent studies on refeeding syndrome (RFS) in critically ill patients and provide clinical recommendations, including the role of electrolyte supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that electrolyte and vitamin supplementation alone is insufficient for treating RFS in critically ill patients, recommending caloric restriction and gradual intake increase. Refeeding hypophosphatemia is common, but correlations between risk factors and RFS occurrence remain unclear.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients at risk of or experiencing refeeding syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of electrolytes in influencing the production of hemolytic factors by pathogenic Candida species.
results_summary: The study found that hemolytic factor production by Candida species is affected by electrolytes, among other factors, but no intraspecies differences in beta-hemolytic activities were observed among common Candida species. Further research is needed to understand the biochemical nature and mechanisms of hemolysis.
population_specificity: Pathogenic Candida species (C. albicans, C. glabrata, C. krusei, C. tropicalis, and C. parapsilosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerability and effectiveness of a proprietary multi-ingredient lipid-lowering supplement (PMILLS) in subjects with dyslipidemia.
results_summary: The PMILLS significantly improved lipid parameters (e.g., reduced LDL-C, TC, TG, and inflammatory markers) and increased HDL-P and LDL particle size, with no adverse effects reported.
population_specificity: 40 participants with dyslipidemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of medical and dietary interventions, specifically oral potassium citrate, for preventing recurrent idiopathic urinary stones in children aged 1 to 18 years.
results_summary: The study found that potassium citrate may lower stone recurrence rates (RR 0.19), but 12.5% of children discontinued due to adverse effects. Evidence quality was low due to study limitations and incomplete adverse event data.
population_specificity: Children (1-18 years) with calcium-containing idiopathic nephrolithiasis and normal renal morphology post-shockwave lithotripsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of water versus carbohydrate-supplemented water on plasma, blood volume, and electrolyte shifts during intermittent high-intensity exercise.
results_summary: Carbohydrate supplementation stabilized plasma sodium levels during exercise, unlike water, which led to decreased sodium and chloride levels. Blood volume partially recovered with water but not with carbohydrate supplementation, despite similar plasma volume reductions in both conditions.
population_specificity: Ten male subjects
effective_dosage: 4 ml/kg/15 min of either tap water or a 9.1% carbohydrate solution
study_duration: Intermittent exercise test performed twice (duration not specified)
